text: this is Ben Bradlee a chief theater
critic of the New York Times for me 2010
will be most fondly remembered as the
year GATS finally made it to New York
City this extraordinary production from
the elevator repair service is a
word-for-word presentation of f scott
Fitzgerald's immortal novel of the Jazz
Age The Great Gatsby now Gatz had been
circling Manhattan for years but unable
to land because of permission problems
with the Fitzgerald estate so even
before it got here it had acquired this
aura of legend befitting the portrait of
a mythic man the miracle is that when it
opened at the public theater this fall
Katz did not disappoint the theater
servitude these days with plays adapted
from other mediums books movies TV shows
but as directed by John Collins Gatz
became something singular ahem - the act
of reading itself of being seduced into
another world by gorgeous sets of
sentences said in a shabby office Gatz
began with the discovery of a copy of
Gatsby by Scott Shepherd the actor who
began reading in a flat voice that
little by little took on a fascinated
animation and lo and behold his bored
looking fellow office workers seemed to
be transformed into Fitzgerald's cast of
characters with almost subliminal
changes in lighting and sound effects
you were caught up in the whirlwind of
these destructive lives that Fitzgerald
depicted so vividly we were all living
vicariously through mr. Shepherds
perfectly modulated perfectly human
common reader suddenly before you knew
it more than six hours had passed and
you had that drugged transfixed feeling
from waking up from a really great read
I'm Ben Brantley of the New York Times
